content.description: Start at the seaward end of the small cliff next to Palm Tree. Work up an overhanging flake to a mantel, and finish on easy ground to the top.
content.location: This is on the east end of the small cliff towards the public beach when standing at the Palm Tree Boulder.

content.description: Start at the two crimps and head right to the Thank-God-Jug (V1+) or the crack's undercling (V2). Stay on the crack until the arete, where you top out on good slopers.Â
content.protection: Two pads or good spotter. Dragging the pad on rocks sucks though.
content.location:
Start at Singing Beach, and head left.

 This is located in the same alcove as Palm Tree. The boulder will be opposite Palm Tree, at the base of the long slab to the beachfront homes.

 Go at low tide. You want the rock dry.

content.description: Start in the cave with two sidepulls, and head to the jug on the lip. Climb on the slab, and top out.
content.location:
Start at Singing Beach, and head left.

 This is located in the same alcove as Palm Tree. The boulder will be opposite Palm Tree, at the base of the long slab to the beachfront homes.

 Go at low tide, slab should be dry to climb.

content.description: Stand start with your left hand on good undercling and your right hand in the crack. Move up to a good face hold. Continue using small face holds on left face and good holds on the arete. There is a sit that is at least a grade harder.
content.location: This is on the wall sitting on the slab hillside, all the way to the right at the low point.

content.description: Sit start the slopey boulder starting at the low point. Tricky feet and barely-there-hands brings you around the corner to a relatively easy topout. There is an option to exit about 2/3rds the way in, but stick to the traverse, and enjoy the rest of the slopers around the corner.
content.location: It is on the far side of the large but short boulder lying on the angled slab at the base of the small cliff.

content.description: Sit start, and climb up and right traversing around a bulge on good holds with tricky feet. This is only climbable during low to medium-low tide.
content.location: Facing the Palm Tree, turn around. There is a large boulder in front of you. Walk to the other side of the boulder, and start the climb at the low point near the water.

content.description:
Sit start hugging the arete. Power move to the slopers, mantel, and top out. Head right to descend or hop on the boulder behind the start. 

 There are great holds through and through and lots of options when topping out. You need a pad or two to protect against the small boulder behind the start.
content.location: Start at Singing Beach, and head left. This is located in the same alcove as Palm Tree. The boulder will be opposite Palm Tree, at the base of the long slab to the beachfront homes. Go at low tide, but no need for dry rock.

content.description:
Stand start at the cliff weakness and work your way up through decent holds. There are a few variations. A sit is possible and is a bit harder. 

 There are likely some harder lines on this cliff.
content.location: It is on the small jagged cliff next to Palm Tree.

content.description: Sit start at the low point. There are multiple options for your hands and feet. Head up and right following the fin.
content.location: On the way out to Palm Tree, there is a wall with an angled slab at its base. This climb starts at the lowest point to the right.

content.description:
Start at the two crimps, and head right to the big undercling on the diagonal crack (yellow line). Stay on the crack until the arete, where you top out on good slopers. You can't use any jugs above below before or after the crack.

 This is a harder variation of Speak to the Manager (V1+).
content.location:
Start at Singing Beach, and head left.

 This is located in the same alcove as Palm Tree. The boulder will be opposite Palm Tree, at the base of the long slab to the beachfront homes.

 Go at low tide. You want the rock dry.

content.description: Singing Beach is a popular summer spot in Manchester-by-the-sea. There is a small crag with two good sized boulders and a small jagged cliff to the north of the sand in a nice alcove. It is a really nice spot on a hot summer day. There is also a few problems on the way to the alcove. Getting down to where the Palm Tree is and Low Tide boulder requires 5.3 climbing if the tide is high. Property along the shore that is above the tide zone is private, so keep this in mind if you want to visit the boulders.
